title: heroic teacher who delivered meals
story: Exclusive: Hero teacher who delivered food to desperate kids sees no sign of levelling upDuring lockdown Zane Powles, , walked more than  miles to hand out , meals but says hes not seen any change at all in his areaZane Powles says he has seen no evidence of levelling up where he lives Image: Andy Commins   Daily MirrorByLucy ThorntonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA teacher awarded an MBE for delivering thousands of school meals to desperate families during lockdown warns he has seen no sign of levelling up in his area. Zane Powles, , walked more than  miles to hand out , meals, help kids with homework and counsel distressed parents. The assistant head at Western Primary School, Grimsby, Lincs, said: “I have not seen any change at all apart from people saying the phrase aposWe’re levelling up’. “HS is not happening now. It feels like all the money is going down south as always.” Read MoreThe former Grenadier Guard said he feared for families left struggling due to the £-a-week Universal Credit cut back.He said: “Money needs to go to these families. There are families who live in houses with no carpets and no wallpaper on the wall. “They do the very best they can for the kids based on the money they have and the skills they have. “Some things take a back seat such as the house decorations. “All the money they get they spend on the essentials, like power and food.” Levelling up is supposed to be the big idea of Boris Johnson’s government.When he was elected in  he pledged to spread opportunity to every corner of the UK. But two years later we are still waiting for the Prime Minister to deliver on his promises. A White Paper setting out the Government’s plan was supposed to have been published this month but has now been shelved until the new year.Many are starting to question whether Mr Johnson is genuinely committed to spreading wealth and opportunity orlevelling up is just an empty slogan. That is why the Mirror is today launching Levelling Up Watch. We intend to hold the Government to account over its plans to improve schools, communities, education and transport. We also want to see any additional money distributed fairly and not just to seats the Tories need to retain to stay in power. What is clear is tinkering with the structure of local government and sprinkling money on piecemeal transport schemes will not be enough. The regional inequality in Britain is not only deep and engrained, it has become starker since the Conservatives came to power in . During that period more than , Sure Start Centres have closed, local councils have seen their funding cut by more than % and the budgets for public health and education have been badly squeezed. The National Audit Office found that since , funding in the most deprived fth of schools fell in real terms by .%, while funding in the fth least deprived schools rose by .%. The additional money announced by Chancellor Rishi Sunak in his Budget will onlyper pupil funding to  levels. People in poorer areas are likely to have worse health and shorter le expectancy but the budget for Public Health England in - is % – £billion – lower in real terms than in -. Nor can it be right that - transport spending was £ per capita in London, compared to £ in the North East and £ in Yorkshire and Humber. We have heard plenty of words from Mr Johnson about his ambitions to level up but the time for rhetoric is over. We need to see some action.  Expensive public transport is the only way some people have of getting around, he said. He added: “In London, you have to wait five minutes for a Tube but here you have to wait three days for a bus. If you get [to Louth] on Saturday the next one [back] is Monday. I am not joking. I think it is £ per adult. “People in the north know that levelling up is not going to happen, it’s just a soundbite and that’s all it’s only going to ever be.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationPublic transportLevelling Up Watch" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: nadhim zahawi admits planning quarter
story: Nadhim Zahawi admits planning for a QUARTER of school staff being off with CovidThe Education Secretary said the next two weeks would be bumpy as he warned of rising infectionsSchools have started reopening after the Christmas break Image: Getty ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe Education Secretary has admitted to planning for a quarter of school staff being off with Covid as he warned absences would increase this week. Nadhim Zahawi said staff absenteeism was around .% last week as schools began to reopen after Christmas, up from % at the end of last term. But he warned that numbers will increase, no doubt, because obviously now schools are back weaposre going to see an increase in infection rates.Ministers are making contingency plans for rising numbers of staff being off with some schools facing absences of up % but still keeping their doors open. We have to make plans for every outcome, thataposs the responsible thing to do, Mr Zahawi told BBC Sunday Morning. I have to have contingency plans for , , , % absenteeism because obviously Omicron is far more infectious. He said the vaccine rollout for  to -year-olds needed to go much faster after the Government missed its target to jab the majority of younger teens by the October half term. Only around half of this age group have had the jab, Mr Zahawi said. We have to go much, much faster which is why we are going back into schools on Monday with the school age vaccination programme, he said. The Cabinet Minister said Covid would eventually become endemic and people would live with the virus. But he added: The next two weeks will be bumpy as staff absenteeism will rise as students go back into education. On the whole, this has been a good start last week. This week will be important. He also backed calls for the Covid self-isolation period to be cut to five daysexperts deem it safe, in order to ease staff shortages. It comes are grim warnings from heads that schools are teetering on the edge with more than a third reporting staff absence levels of over % due to Covid on the first day of term.The poll of nearly , school leaders in England by the NAHT union came amid mounting fears over fresh disruption to childrenaposs learning. The snap survey found the majorityof heads had pupils absent due to Covid, while nearly a thirdreported over % of children were out of class because of the virus. Paul Whiteman, general secretary of NAHT, said: “Schools are doing everything they can to maintain education for pupils in the face of very challenging circumstances. Staff absence on the first day of term was considerable and could very likely rise as the term progresses.” Mr Zahawi also insisted that exams would go ahead this summer, with more details to come next month on the measures needed to make assessments fair for pupils. He said: My absolute commitment is that exams are going ahead both this January and for the summer, for GCSEs and A-levels, but weaposre putting in mitigations to make sure that we recognise who have had their education disruption. title: over promising under delivering hallmark
story: Over-promising and under-delivering is a hallmark of Prime Minister Boris JohnsonToday the Daily Mirror takes a detailed look at le in areas the Conservatives claim they now care about with the launch of our Levelling up Watch - and the picture is bleakWales Highschool is in desperate need of investment Image: SWNSopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Jan | commentsAs empty political slogans go, “Levelling Up” must be among the emptiest ever created by masters of the art the Tories. Today the Daily Mirror takes a detailed look at le in areas the Conservatives claim they now care about. The picture is bleak, with little or no progress since Boris Johnson won an -seat majority at the  General Election. Over-promising and under-delivering is a hallmark of this Prime Minister. The rundown school we highlight today, where heroic teachers and other staff struggle to keep going in crumbling buildings, is unfortunately not an exception. Working people deserve better and the pupils deserve an education in fit-for-purpose facilities. But in this country Government policies are levelling us down instead of up. Staff our NHS  With an understaffed NHS on its knees, axing key staff because they are unvaccinated would be self-destructive. The boss of one of London’s busiest hospitals warning as many as % of his workforce could need moving shows what happens when the tricky real world collides with Whitehall diktat. Of course, those in the health service should be jabbed, to protect patients, colleagues and the public as well as themselves. Yet the no jab, no job order could prove ruinous to the provision of healthcare. Daily pre-work tests are expensive and burdensome but it would surely be better to use them than to lose the skills and expertise of people who, for whatever reason, have failed to get inoculated, or chosen not to. Pitch in, Andy The Duke of York’s ongoing legal troubles in the US civil courts cast a dark shadow over the Queen’s planned Platinum Jubilee celebrations in early June. If Prince Andrew wants to make a positive contribution to the national occasion, he should bake his mum a cake to mark it. It’d be no sweat. title: tory mp who rapped over
story: Exclusive: Tory MP who was rapped over sexism quietly replaced on Women and Equalities CommitteeLee Anderson made headlines last year for boycotting the Euro football tournament because he did not like the "the taking the knee business.” Image: Daily Mirror Andy StenningByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsAn MP who boycotted the Euros because of footballers players taking the knee has quietly left the Women and Equalities Committee. Ashfield MP Lee Anderson was recently criticised for telling a female district councillor in his constituency to “stay out of big boy’s politics”. The Tories appointed him to the committee in May last year, despite having reprimanded him over sexist behaviour. But after just six months on the committee, he was quietly replaced in mid-December by former equalities minister Caroline Dineage. Mr Anderson has not publicly addressed his stepping back from the committee, and did not respond to a request for comment. Commons records show he left the Committee on December . Mr Anderson made headlines during the Euro  tournament for announcing he would not watch England matches because he did not like “the taking the knee business.” Mr Anderson was “warned” by Conservative party in  over a Facebook post while he was a Councillor.Alongside a picture of a woman wearing a low-cut tank top, Mr Anderson wrote: “Out with some great knockers tonight in Skegby.” In November, he sparked fury in his local constituency by telling Ashfield District Councillor Samantha Deakin to “stay out of big boy’s politics.” Cllr Deakin had criticised Mr Anderson in a row about a local college. “Like many people, Lee Anderson’s appointment to the Women’s and Equality Select Committee was a surprise to me,” she said. “ More than that - it was an insult. Since then, I have been a victim of his misogyny.” She added: “We asked the Conservative Party last year whether his current membership of this important committee was appropriate – they didn’t reply. “It’s clear however that someone has agreed and this Select Committee can now get on with their job without the influence of someone with the views of a s Working Men’s Club comedian.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Lee AndersonConservative PartyThe EuroPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory slammed backing struggling oil
story: Tory slammed for backing struggling oil and gas giants as Labour demand windfall taxLabour would impose a windfall tax on North Sea oil and gas producers to ease the cost of living squeeze - reducing the average household energy bill by £Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said a windfall tax on struggling oil and gas giants doesnt add up Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsTory minister Nadhim Zahawi has been criticised for defending struggling North Sea oil and gas giants while hard-pressed families face soaring energy bills. The Education Secretary rejected Labouraposs plans for a one-off windfall tax on the fossil fuel firms to help support consumers claiming they donapost add up. Mr Zahawi, a former oil industry advisor, claimed the rise in the national living wage would help people cope with rising energy costs which are set to add hundreds of pounds to average bills. The biggest British energy firms, BP and Shell, raked in £.bn in three months last year and the boss of BP has called the market a cash machine. Mr Zahawi told LBC: I was a businessman before I entered Parliament and I can tell you what Labour are putting out just doesnapost add up.  A windfall tax on oil and gas companies, who are already struggling in the North Sea, is never going to cut it.He said the Government had poured £.million into helping those most in need - and said looming National Insurance hike was a progressive way to raise funds for the NHS and social care.But Shadow Financial Secretary to the Treasury James Murray said: Rather than supporting hard-working people facing huge energy bill rises, Government ministers are pleading poverty on behalf of oil companies who are enjoying record profits.” Labour would impose a windfall tax on North Sea oil and gas producers to fund measures to ease the cost of living squeeze, by reducing the average household energy bill by £.The £.bn plan would include removing VAT on domestic energy bills for a whole year, as well as expanding and increasing the warm homes discount for those most at risk. Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves blamed ministers for creating a “price crisis” by responding to surging wholesale energy costs with “dither and delay”.  Under Labouraposs plan, fossil fuel giants would be forced to contribute £.bn to help fund the proposals, through a year-long increase to their corporation tax of %. Ms Reeves told Sky: The Prime Minister was the biggest advocate for cutting VAT on gas and electricity bills during the European referendum. But now when cutting those bills would make more dference than ever, the Prime Minister says no. The Shadow Chancellor said thatnow was not the time to cut VAT on energy bills then frankly I donapost know when is. She added: Bills canapost be paid on broken promises. title: uproar colston statue verdict another
story: Uproar about Colston statue verdict is another Tory tactic to distractForget record high NHS waiting lists and crumbling schools when Tory Cabinet Ministers lie in front of giant Union Jacks to illustrate their intense patriotism, says Kevin MaguireDont worry about declining living standards because Boris Johnson is going to save statues of slave traders, says Kevin Maguire Image: PAopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Jan | commentsDonapost worry about declining living standards because Boris Johnson is going to save statues of slave traders. Forget record high NHS waiting lists and crumbling schools when Tory Cabinet Ministers lie in front of giant Union Jacks to illustrate their intense patriotism. And ignore sleaze, corruption, back-handers, unfairness, inequality and fatal mistakes for, with the blessing of Culture Wars Secretary Nadine Dorries, Tory no-mark Andrew Rosindell wants the BBC to play God Save the Queen every day. Statues, flags and anthems are battlegrounds the PM’s smokescreen to ert public attention away from his tax hikes, soaring fuel bills, cost of living rises, stagnant wages and declining public services.  It is a classic, cynical Right-wing strategy to ide and rule. It played well in the past and it might work again. Magicians use misdirection as a form of deception to draw the audience’s attention from the real action. Johnson would rather voters were angry about a jury clearing four protesters over the toppling of slaver Edward Colston’s statue in Bristol than holding the PM to account for increased National Insurance or discussing Labour’s proposed windfall tax on North Sea oil and gas producers to compensate households who are facing huge increases in energy bills. Suella Braverman is an Attorney-General whose ideological conviction results in much of the legal profession judging her guilty of stupidity. Even considering an appeal against the jury verdict in the Colston case is a sign the governing party will roll in the gutter. Labour leader Keir Starmer is wise to take no lectures on patriotism from a Conservative regime which inflicted the terrible national self-harm that is Brexit. But in a fight, the Labour leader is similarly wise to combat smears which saw predecessor Jeremy Corbyn unfairly tainted as hating his country. Labour wins by keeping the national conversation on big issues that really count, the Tories by changing it to emblems and frippery. Living standards or statues  The election’s choice and verdict will decide whether Britain is a progressive country moving brightly forward or stuck in the past. title: bridal boutique owner left speechless
story: Bridal boutique owner left speechless by brutal note comparing shop to prisonThe four-page onslaught which slams Taras decor, her displays, and even lashes out at her customer care for brides was posted to the studio as an anonymous handwritten noteTara was left stunned when she opened the letter and read its contents Image: Kennedy News and MediaByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe owner of a bridal boutique was left speechless when she received a handwritten note comparing her shop to a prison cell and a graveyard. Tara Trethowan, , describes running her independent bridal wear shop, The Bridal Studio in Cornwall, as aposmore of a vocationapos than a job, putting love into everything she does. But after discovering a letter on November , Tara was shocked to find it was a handwritten four-page rant, lashing out at nearly every aspect of her business, including comparing the walls to prison cell grey and flowers from a graveyard. The confused mum-of-three who has been running the shop since  posted the note on social media in a bid to find the anonymous critic, with many soon coming to the business owners defence online.  Tara said: Itaposs pretty ridiculous. Usually when we get letters they are from brides with a photograph of them in their dress thanking us for helping them. We didnapost really know what to make of it and at first thought it was maybe a bit of a joke. We donapost usually get handwritten letters, it was a bit of a shock.If somebody felt aggrieved by our windows and they were so upset about it then why didnapost they sign the letter, e-mail us or write a Google review. At first I was disappointed to think that somebody felt like that about us because I put a lot of effort and love into what I do. I havenapost got a clue who wrote the letter, thataposs the million-dollar question. The note goes on to describe Taraaposs shop as uninspiring and unattractive and wasting a prime high street position with thoughtless displays, as well as suggesting Tara doesnapost care about her brides. Throughout the nameless author aggressively tries to advise what they think she should do with the displays, encouraging her to go to other bridal boutiques, dress the mannequins instead of dumping the gowns on them, and tells her to buy decorations from The Range.  The anonymous writer said the letter was dficult to write and that Taraaposs displays should be full of joy. Tara added: It isnapost a job, itaposs like a vocation really. I love what we do and feel very privileged to be able to help brides find their dress. So to get a letter like that my first thoughts were aposwow, god Iaposve really upset somebodyapos. But as itaposs gone on Iaposm thinking that it was somebody whoaposs got a bit too much time on their hands and I got it in the neck for whatever reason. Everybody has an opinion and itaposs all subjective but Iaposm genuinely keen to know what drove them to write it.  Now however the writer of the scathing note has come under fire themselves after Taraaposs social media post racked up more than , likes, with many condemning the letter. One person said the letter was an absolute load of b*******. Sam Jane wrote: I despair of the human race sometimes. So bloody rude and thoughtless. Christine Woods said: Oh my goodness, this beggars belief. Everyone has an opinion but why not put your name on it. Charlotte Emily White commented: This is literally so savage, uncalled for and inaccurate. This person is a k*ob And Judith Oliver weighed and said: I look forward to seeing your windows whenever Iaposm in or passing through Helston. Tara welcomed the person to come forward and offer any expertise they may have. She said that she is always trying to improve her businesses and is happy to hear constructive criticism. title: case against madeleine mccann prime
story: Case against Madeleine McCann prime suspect set to crumble as alibi stacks upKnown sex predator Christian Brueckner was just " minutes" from Praia De Luz on the night Madeleine McCann disappeared but now investigators may have to dismiss him as a suspect, it has been reportedThere were hopeful leads but the case to find out what happened to Madeleine McCann is set to crumble, it has been reported Image: PAByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  The prime suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann may have to be dismissed after British investigators suggested his alibi stacks up, it has been reported.Ongoing investigations led by an ex detective found that known sex predator, Christian Brueckner, , was just  minutes from the Portuguese resort where the three year old was staying when she vanished in . Madeleine was just three years old when she vanished while holidaying with her family in PortugalThe probe led by former Surrey Police detective, Mark Williams-Thomas, had been investigating B who is currently in jail in Germany, where authorities believe he killed Madeleine.  Phone records were said to show him near the scene in Praia De Luz the night she disappeared. But the latest developments suggest his alibi aposstacks upapos. Their case against him, which is being covered on TV in the series Madeleine McCann: Investigating the Prime Suspect is set to crumble after two witnesses in Portugal and Germany have thrown his guilt into doubt, it has been reported.Our source told The Sun : “They have concluded Brueckner could not have snatched Madeleine. He was  minutes away and was not on the phone in Praia da Luz the night she vanished.” Madeleine would have marked her th birthday this year, which becomes the th year since she was snatched from her family.Born on May , , in Leicester, the tot grew up with her family in the quaint and leafy village of Rothley, with her parents, Gerry and Kate and younger twin siblings, Amelie and Sean. The parents said they had put all the kids to bed in their ground floor apartment at .pm and were dining out with friends just  metres away when they realised Maddie was missing but an hour and  minutes later. News of the case travelled the globe and several suspects were quizzed but later released. In the early years, as the investigation failed to find any useful leads, the case was closed in . Her parents set up Madeleineaposs Fund: Leaving No Stone Unturned Ltd  days after she disappeared to help cover the cost of efforts to find her. Less than a year later in March  it was reported to have received over £. million and today the search to find Madeleine has spent over £ million. Channel  TV crews have been following the case in Germany and Portugal for months, and the three part documentary is set to air soon. title: couple spend 16000 van ebay
story: Couple spend £, on van off of eBay and travel Europe with their DalmatianVinny and Natasha Ware spent a year doing up the Peugeot Boxer before embarking on a whirlwind tour chasing the sun across Europe with their loyal pooch, Pippa, by their sideNatasha and Vinny Ware travelled across Europe in a van they bought off eBay Image: @waresnext Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByLucy NotarantonioMatt Strudwick:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A couple spent £, on a van off eBay and converted it into the perfect mobile home in order to travel across Europe with their Dalmatian.Natasha and Vinny Ware took more than a year doing up the old Peugeot Boxer which had its own shower, kitchen, solar , diesel heater, portable toilet, hob, and even a bed for their pet pooch, Pippa. The married couple bought the used Peugeot Boxer for just £, from ebay and spent a further £, doing it up. Natasha and Vinny then embarked on a whirlwind tour across Europe where Pippa strolled through Valencia city centre, hiked in En Xativa, Spain, drank fresh water in Lauterbrunnen, Switzerland, chased kites in La Manga and sunbathed in Benalmadena, Spain. Natasha, , said: “It felt so liberating being able to go everywhere and anywhere we like. We had everything we needed in the camper van including our dog. “She loved cruising along with us and going for dferent walks in the Swiss mountains or on a Spanish beach.” The tour started in October from their home in Abergele, Wales, and saw the couple travel to Switzerland, Spain, France and Italy before ing to the UK on December , . Vinny used to be a builder for  years so he is very handy, said Natasha. He did an amazing job. The van has a pull out double bed but is spacious as there’s only two of us. “We didn’t feel cramped at all during our trip - even with Pippa. She had her own bed but mostly stayed in ours. It was amazing waking up daily to dferent scenery with Pippa by our side. “She looked so happy to be with us. The only dficulty was wanting to go somewhere without her such as a restaurant for dinner. We had to make sure we were parked somewhere safe. “We would only leave her for an hour or two.” And what was the best thing about travelling in a van  Natasha said it was the freedom.  We could just get up and go every few days, she said. “We were mainly chasing the sun so spent a lot of time in Spain but we did drive through France and spent a day in Italy. Pippa has a lot of energy as she is a Dalmatian so she was happy to walk everywhere too.” The couple now allow members of the public to hire their silver van. She adds: “With everything going on in the world at the moment, people are opting for staycations. So we have put the van on multiple sites including Air BnB for £ per night including insurance. “We want other people and dogs to enjoy our quirky mobile home.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON eBayHolidaysDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid much more likely cause
story: Covid much more likely to cause heart problems in teens than the jab, research showsMillions of -to--year-olds have the option of taking up a second Covid vaccine from tomorrow as efforts are increased prevent the spread of highly transmissible Omicron iantCovid is much more likely to cause heart problems among teenagers than from the vaccine., research has shown Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsCovid is much more likely to cause heart problems among teenagers than from the vaccine., research has shown. Millions of -to--year-olds have the option of taking up a second jab from tomorrow as efforts are increased prevent the spread of Omicron iant.But  per cent of that age group in England have yet to sign-up for a first dose since the Covid jab was offered to them in late September.Among -to--year-olds the figure is slightly better, so the reasons why youngsters are not signing up is not clear.But vaccines have been linked to very rare cases of myocarditis, where muscles in the heart become inflamed causing chest pain, breathlessness, a pounding pulse and nausea.The condition can develop after a viral infection such as flu and the heart is aposinjuredapos by Covid or by the immune system’s reaction to it.  Men are more likely to be affected by myocarditis than women as the male hormone testosterone hampers cells in the body which can reduce inflammation. Dr Mohiddin, consultant cardiologist at Barts Heart Centre in London said: There’s a striking predisposition to myocarditis in younger men, which may be to do with their higher levels of hormones They usually develop heart problems about  days or so after viral infection, but in  per cent of cases it’s mild and they make a complete recovery. Myocarditis has been linked to very rare cases in the Pfizer jab among teens and the Moderna jab as a booster in over-s. But there is no evidence that the Oxford- AstraZeneca vaccine triggers it. Sir Chris Whitty announced plans in the autumn to vaccinate teenagers and said there was only a marginal benefit in health terms They were offered the jab to keep schools open as much as possible and prevent disruption to pupils’ education. Scientists from Edinburgh and Oxford universities last month found that for every million second doses of the Pfizer given to those aged  to  in the UK, there were three cases of myocarditis. Health experts say Covid vaccine risks of myocarditis are small. Dr Mohiddin told the Daily Mail : My message to worried parents would be that the risks from teenagers not being vaccinated are greater than being vaccinated – even with milder Omicron in circulation.The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency, which monitors drug safety in the UK, there were  reports of myocarditis in all age groups following the Pfizer jab up to December m, but it led to four deaths It adds: The majority of fatal reports describe underlying illnesses in these patients that could provide an alternative explanation. Under-s should wait at least  weeks after having Covid infection to have a first or second vaccine government advice says. But the risk of heart problems could be highera teenage boy catches the virus without knowing and shows no symptoms Doctors say it’s impossible to say but any increase in risk would be small and myocarditis would be very mild. title: covid should treated like flu
story: Covid should be treated like flu and mass vaccination needs to end, ex-jab chief saysDr Clive Dix helped pharmaceutical companies create Covid jabs and is a supporter of the booster campaign, but he said it is now time for hte UK to change tact andto a "new normality"Prime Minister Boris Johnson looks on while a man receives his coronavirus vaccine Image: Getty ImagesByMatt Strudwick:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The ex-chief of the UKaposs vaccine taskforce says coronavirus should be treated like the flu and the mass vaccine programme should be scrapped after the booster campaign has ended.Dr Clive Dix thinks the country shouldto a new normality and we now need to manage the disease rather than stop its spread.The former chairman of the governmentaposs vaccine taskforce from December  to April  added stopping progression to severe disease in vulnerable groups is the future objective. “We need to analyse whether we use the current booster campaign to ensure the vulnerable are protected,this is seen to be necessary,” he said. “Mass population-based vaccination in the UK should now end.” He called on ministers to urgently support research into Covid immunity beyond antibodies as it could help create vaccines for vulnerable people specic to Covid iants. Dr Dix helped pharmaceutical companies create the Covid jabs that have aided vulnerable peopleaposs protection from Covid, and though he supported the booster campaign he told The Observer a new strategy was needed.“We should consider when we stop testing and let iniduals isolate when they are not well andto work when they feel ready, in the same way we do in a bad influenza season,” he said. His comments come on the back of the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , which advises the governmentaposs vaccine policy, saying that a fourth Covid jab is not yet needed. Professor Wei Shen Lim, the JCVIaposs chairman of Covid- immunisation, said: The current data show the booster dose is continuing to provide high levels of protection against severe disease, even for the most vulnerable older age groups. This is highly encouraging and emphasises the value of a booster jab. With Omicron continuing to spread widely, I encourage everyone to come forwards for their booster dose, orunvaccinated, for their first two doses, to increase their protection against serious illness.Prof Anthony Harnden, deputy chairman of the JCVI, told BBC Radio aposs Today programme that it was important to get the timing right for any potential fourth dose of a vaccine for vulnerable people.Which may be later in the year... we just donapost think itaposs the right time at the moment, he said.Yesterday, the UK became the first country in Europe to pass , Covid-related deaths since the start of the pandemic. A grim statistic that Sir Keir Starmer labelled a dark milestone for our country. Writing on Twitter, the Labour leader said: Our thoughts are with all those who have lost someone, and we thank everyone supporting the vaccination effort. We must ensure the public inquiry provides answers and that lessons are learned. Prof Harnden said “it is absolutely tragic, and added: “I think we could have done better. I think some of the deaths are even more tragic for the fact that many of them were avoidablewe had acted earlier in the first and second wave.”In a statement on his Twitter account, Boris Johnson said: “ Coronavirus has taken a terrible toll on our country and today the number of deaths recorded has reached ,.“Each and every one of those is a profound loss to the families, friends and communities affected and my thoughts and condolences are with them. “Our way out of this pandemic is for everyone to get their booster or their first or second dosethey haven’t yet.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FluCoronavirusCoronavirus vaccineBoris JohnsonKeir Starmer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news deltacron-iant-found-cyprus-not-"Boris Johnson says battle against Omicron is not overByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Scientists have poured water on claims that a new iant combining the Delta and Omicron Covid strains has emerged - saying contamination is likely to blame.Reports emerged this weekend that a new Covid strain - branded Deltacron - had been discovered in a lab in Cyprus. But sceptical experts said this is unlikely to be the case - with a World Health Organisation scientist emphatically stating Deltacron is not real. Imperial College virologist Dr Tom Peacock is among the experts saying the anomaly appears to be quite clearly contamination as it does not meet the criteria for a new iant.And World Health OrganisationCovid expert Dr Krutika Kuppalli posted on Twitter : Deltacron is not real and is likely due to sequencing artact .Let’s not merge of names of infectious diseases and leave it to celebrity couples.  The response from the scientic community came after Leondios Kostrikis, professor of biological sciences at the University of Cyprus, said his team had discovered  Covid samples which appeared to combine the Delta and Omicron strains. He told reporters: There are currently omicron and delta co-infections and we found this strain that is a combination of these two. It sparked a huge response on social media, with Deltacron trending for much of the weekend, but experts are not convinced. Dr Peacock wrote in response: The Cypriot aposDeltacronapos sequences reported by several large media outlets look to be quite clearly contamination - they do not cluster on a phylogenetic tree and have a whole Artic primer sequencing amplicon of Omicron in an otherwise Delta backbone.  In a y Twitter thread debunking the iant, he said: Delta sequences with strange mutations in amplicon  have been turning up for ageshowever, they always show this non-monophyletic pattern and are nearly always more easily explained by this primer issue exacerbating very low-level contam.Global health expert Dr Boghuma Kabisen Titanji posted on Twitter: On the #Deltacron story, just because I have been asked about it many times in the last h, please interpret with caution. The information currently available is pointing to contamination of a sample as opposed to true recombination of #Delta and #Omicron iants.She added: The best thing we can do besides worrying about it and coining iant names that sound like a Transformers villain, is ensuring that vaccines are available to everyone and combining vaccination with other strategies that give the virus fewer opportunities to spread. Prof Martin Michaelis, Professor of Molecular Medicine at the University of Kent, told The Mirror that it is not yet clear whether the samples are real, or the rest of a sequencing error or contamination.He said: As far as I can tell, researchers from Cyprus have sequenced samples of SARS-CoV-, the coronavirus that causes COVID-, and received genomic sequences that combine features of the Omicron and Delta iants.It is not yet clear whether this is real or a sequencing error or the consequence of contamination. If dferent viruses from dferent SARS-CoV- iants are analysed on the same machines, you can get sequences that look asthey are from a new virus but are in reality just a mixture of dferent viruses. Hence, we have to wait for what further investigations will show. In any case, Deltacron is not an official name. But he warned thattwo viruses infect the same cell, there is potential for strains to combine - meaning a hybrid iant is formed. Prof Michaelis continued: Coronaviruses including SARS-CoV- have in principle the ability to recombine their genetic materialtwo viruses infect the same cell. Therefore, it is possible thatsomeone is simultaneously infected with an Omicron and a Delta iant virus that new hybrid viruses emerge that carry a new combination of the features of the two original viruses. With high levels of Omicron and Delta transmission at the same time, such hybrid viruses may be formed at some point. title: devastated family young man who
story: Devastated family of young man who died after arrest demand police bodycam footageMohamud Mohammed Hassan, , who was due to become a dad, died the day he was released from custody at Cardf Bay police station a year ago and a year later - his family are still seeking answersExpectant dad Mohamud Hassan died the day he was released from police custody Image: Media WalesByBronwen WeatherbyDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan The family of a young man found dead after being released from police custody today demanded footage to be released a year after his death. Protesters today demonstrated outside Cardf Bay police station, where Mohamud Mohammed Hassan, , was taken on January  last year. Mr Hassan, who was due to become a dad, was released the following morning but died the next day. He ed home that day battered and bruised after being assaulted by police officers during his time in custody. So far six members of South Wales Police, four officers and two custody sergeants have been served misconduct notices.  A post-mortem examination failed to establish the cause of Mr Hassanaposs death. An inquest into his death will be held at South Wales Central Coroneraposs Court in Pontypridd in May. Meanwhile, an investigation by the Independent Office for Police Conductis still underway. Now his family has called for honesty and answers. They say they believe both the police force and IOPC have conspired to cover up, obscure, frustrate, delay and dispute their search for the truth. They ask that the video footage from Mr Hassanaposs night in the cells be released immediately.  The IOPC has refused to release it in case it may be needed as evidence for criminal, misconduct or inquest proceedings. The family said in a statement: We have repeatedly requested that the IOPC provide the family and our legal team access to the video showing the final hours of Mohamudaposs le. Despite our repeated requests, the family have been consistently denied access by the IOPC. Had the footage of Mohamudaposs last moments been released to us, then we would have been spared the slow torturous agony of consistently speculating day by day on precisely what happened to him that awful night. We believe that all families of those that die in suspicious circumstances in police custody should have an automatic right enshrined in law to get immediate access to police bodycam footage showing exactly what happened during their final moments on this earth.  In stark contrast, we see in the US, after a death in police custody, police bodycam videos being released on demand to families in the immediate aftermath of such incidents. One year on from the untimely and suspicious death of our beloved family member we remain in shock at the treatment we received from IOPC throughout the last year. Six Cardf police officers are now under investigation and the only reason we believe that happened was due to our relentless questioning of the police version of events. Several Black Lives Matter protests and vigils were held outside Cardf Bay police station in the months that followed Mr Hassanaposs death. The family are being backed by Shavanah Taj, general secretary of the Wales TUC, who said: Given historical allegations of institutional racism levelled at South Wales Police and other recent cases of police brutality, we need to ensure that the investigation is subjected to independent legal scrutiny, supported by independent expert witnesses. Zita Holbourne, national chairwoman and co-founder of Black Activists Rising Against Cuts, added: Itaposs a national scandal that a year on the Hassan family have no idea how Mohamud died, and yet both the IOPC and South Wales Police have had unrestricted access to this footage. Itaposs utterly unacceptable, and the attorney general should instruct the IOPC to release the police bodycam footage immediately. Campaign spokesman Lee Jasper said: The release of this footage should be a matter of human rights and families should be given unrestricted access to police bodycam footage. We call on the public to support this critical demand. title: france travel ban to loosened
story: France travel ban to be loosened in good news for Brits hopeful for holidaysBrits are still banned from many countries butyoure dreaming of a Parisian city break, or a holiday on the French Riviera, it might not be a fantasy for too much longerEssential workers are now permitted to travel to France Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments France has hinted that its strict UK travel ban could be loosened as countries start to lt their Covid restrictions on Brits flying in.French ministerial cabinet members have agreed to allow essential workers to enter the country, despite over , new cases recorded within its borders. Spokesperson for the French Government, Gabriel Attal, acknowledged that the news would come as relief for many looking to visit France on a working capacity after the list of compelling reasons, notably professional was extended.But many tourists are still waiting to hear when the rules will be changed for them, after the French government imposed the strict ban on December . It states that all arrivals must have an essential reason to travel to, or come from, the UK, both for the unvaccinated and vaccinated. Initially the list of essential reasons did not include leisure travel or professional reasons, but the latest move has re-introduced the latter as an appropriate purpose of journey. Britain is now also taking steps to make travelling easier, including removal of some pre and post departure tests for arrivals in the UK. Vaccinated passengers no longer need to take a test before they leave for for the UK as of Friday and from am today, vaccinated travellers can take a much cheaper and more convenient lateral flow test rather than the previous day  PCR required.  The changes to these rules do not apply for unvaccinated passengers. The isolation rule has also been scrapped for passengers with a full vaccination passport, meaning they can travel freely as soon as they land, provided their lateral flow isnapost positive. In this case, they will be asked to take a PCR test to confirm the positive result and self isolate immediately. Brits are still banned from a number of countries and remain on the red list of others, including Cyprus. It is still possible to travel to a number of countries, but many of these have made it signicantly easier for vaccinated passengers, such as in Spain, Italy and Germany, where they can enter without self isolation by proving their vaccine status.  Other countries still maintain mandatory pre-departure tests, such as Portugal and Greece as well as the US - but unvaccinated passengers cannot enter the States at all. In New Zealand the strict Managed Isolation Quarantine rules remain and passengers cannot travel to the country without a aposcritical reasonapos. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern did consider the idea of ditching the intense MIQ system currently operating in Aotearoa, however, the rapid spread of the Omicron iant has shelved any plans for a more lenient system to replace it in the immediate future. news uk-news free-lateral-flow-tests-to-"Nadhim Zahawi says free lateral flows will not be scrappedByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsFree lateral flow tests could soon be scrapped for most of the public within weeks, reports claim. Under plans reportedly being weighed up by officials, the tests could soon only be available in high-risk settings such as care homes, hospitals and schools. Boris Johnson is said to be poised to announce the move as part of the Governmentaposs strategy for living with the virus.However government sources have disputed the report and said it is too early to say what will happen with the tests, while Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said there were absolutely not any plans to do scrap them currently.The move would also see the NHS Test and Trace service scaled back, according to The Sunday Times.A Whitehall source told the newspaper: “I don’t think we are in a world where we can continue to hand out free lateral flow tests to everybody forevermore. It’s likely we will move to a scenario where there is less testing but where we have a capacity to ramp it upnecessary, such as in the winter.”  The Mirror has contacted the Department of Health for comment. Mr Zahawi said on Sunday that he was slightly puzzled by the report. Askeduniversal free lateral flows would be scrapped, he told Skyaposs Trevor Phillips on Sunday: This is absolutely not where we are at. For January alone,  million lateral flow tests coming in and they will continue to be available for free. I donapost really recognise where that story is coming from. Pressed on whether there were plans to begin charging for lateral flow tests, he said: Absolutely not.It comes days after the PM announced that from next week people who test positive on a lateral flow test will no longer be required to confirm their condition with a PCR testthey have no symptoms.After the rule change on Tuesday, people who test positive with no symptoms - said to account for around % of people with Covid - will no longer need this follow-up PCR test.They will still have to isolate for at least seven days, but only from the date of their positive lateral flow test.A decision to scrap free lateral flow tests would happen at a time when Covid cases reach record levels, with nearly . million confirmed infections in the past week across the UK. The Office for National Statisticsestimates that one in  people had the virus in the final week of  in England - with Wales and Scotland not far behind with one in  and Northern Ireland with one in . Although the number of people being treated in hospital with Covid has risen to its highest level in months - the number requiring ventilation is at its lowest since October last year. Scientists say increasing evidence shows that the Omicron iant causes less severe illness. Dr Mike Tildesley, a member of the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Modelling group, told Times Radio: “The thing that might happen in the future is you may see the emergence of a new iant that is less severe, and ultimately, in the long term, what happens is Covid becomes endemic and you have a less severe version. It’s very similar to the common cold that we’ve lived with for many years. “We’re not quite there yet but possibly Omicron is the first ray of light there that suggests that may happen in the longer term. It is, of course, much more transmissible than Delta was, which is concerning, but much less severe.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSBoris JohnsonNursing homesPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: grief stricken mum brave boy
story: Grief-stricken mum of brave boy Bradley Lowery left heartbroken again after dad diesGemma Lowery, the mum of inspirational six-year-old Bradley Lowery - whose positivity in the face of a horric cancer diagnosis inspired the nation - has been left "heartbroken" even more after her "hero and rock" dad died of cancer on Friday nightBradley Lowerys mum Gemma announced the tragic loss of her hero and rock dad who died of cancer on Friday Image: Bradley Lowery FoundationBySophie FinneganRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan  The heartbroken mum of Bradley Lowery has asked her late son to look after granddad in heaven after her fatheraposs death from cancer. Gemma Lowery from County Durham said she is heartbroken after her dad - who was her hero and rock - passed away at .pm on Friday night following a short battle with the cruel disease, Chronicle Live reports.In an emotional tribute, Gemma said the family are taking comfort knowing heaposs no longer in pain and has been reunited with little Bradley - who died of a rare and aggressive form of cancer in . The touching post said: Last night at .pm heaven gained another angel and another piece of my heart has gone.My dad, Bradleyaposs grandad [sic], my hero, my rock passed away after a short battle with cancer. There are no words to describe how heartbroken we are as a family but we take comfort knowing he is out of pain and is reunited back with Brad. They were inseparable when on earth and I know they will be with each other now. I miss you already dad, I will always be your little girl and you will always be my hero. Look after grandad Bradley.Six-year-old Bradley tragically lost his fight to a rare and aggressive form of childhood cancer in  with his parents establishing the Bradley Lowery Foundation in his memory. His parents, Gemma and Carl Lowery, welcomed their daughter, Gracie-Mae, into the world at .am on Saturday, November  last year, via an emergency C section at Sunderland Royal Hospital. The family enjoyed Gracieaposs very first Christmas with Gemma admitting it was bittersweet as it was her last one with her amazing dad. Early last year, England star Jermain Defoe revealed in an emotional interview that he thinks of Bradley, who became Sunderland FCaposs mascot, every day. The pair met when the young Sunderland fan, ill with neuroblastoma, was a mascot and Defoe was the Black Cats’ star player.You can find out more about the Bradley Lowery Foundation here. title: hermes driver puts package bin
story: Hermes driver puts package in bin only for it to be emptied by refuse collectorsGary Pebble later found out that the Hermes driver had signed for the pricey package - that contained vital parts - himself with an indistinct “squiggle”Hermes driver leaves signed for package worth £ in the bin Image: Facebook REYLAND MOTORSPORTByMichael MoranMatt Strudwick:,  Jan | comments A Hermes courier has been captured on CCTV stuffing a signed for package into a bin - which then proceeded to be emptied by refuse collectors.In the images the delivery driver can be seen putting the package into a wheelie bin. The pricey package was for saloon racing champ Gary Pebble and contained hundreds of pounds worth of vital spare parts for his Honda Civic EG racing car. Gary even forked out extra to ensure they were securely shipped from Southampton to his Worcestershire-based Reyland Motorsport business. They were delivered on the Bank Holiday Monday at the start of this month when his business was shut for the day.  But rather than taking the package back to schedule a redelivery, Gary later found out when he checked the proof of delivery that the Hermes driver signed for the delivery himself with an indistinct “squiggle”. The driver took a photo as proof of “delivery”, then hops in his vehicle and drives away. To make matters worse, the next day Garyaposs CCTV cameras showed a blue Fortress Recycling truck arrive to collect the rubbish.  But it was not until the following day that Gary realised something was wrong when he chased up the delivery on the car components. He checked his CCTV, and learned the worst. He told the Sun : Watching that video was just soul-destroying.It was worth about £ but it was vital to measure the new part I paid £, for.  Gary now needs to order a new component and mechanic Martin Hadland will need to start the job from scratch – leaving Gary in danger of not being ready for the start of the new season. I have had to order a new part and hope it arrives in time and is fitted before the season starts, he said. Hopefully it will be here, but it is just so annoying. A spokesperson for Hermes said: We are already in contact with the customer and are dealing with the issues. The Mirror has contacted Hermes for further comment. news uk-news heroic-man-saves-stricken-dog-"Isle of Man: Retired police officer rescues missing dachshund from flooded quarryByDouglas WhitbreadMatt Strudwick:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA heroic retired policeman jumped into the freezing waters of a flooded quarry to rescue a dog. Bebe, a dachshund, was found on a ledge just a few feet above the deep water having survived a ft fall. The two-year-old had gone missing, along with six-month-old Lulu, and sparked a major pet hunt when the duo became separated from their owner, Melanie Kermeen. Lulu managed to find her way home, but Melanie only found Bebe when she heard her frightened yelps from the bottom of the pit. But as she waited for help to arrive, retired cop and open swimmer Juan Kinley jumped into the icy waters to rescue Bebe. The dramatic rescue was captured on video and showed the moment when the -year-old former Isle of Man DCI swam over to the pooch and help her back to safety. Melanie, , said she was lucky that someone like Juan was nearby to help rescue her terried dog. She said: “There have been tragic stories where dogs get lost, so it was just a harrowing  hours. “But the way it ended was quite spectacular, and her fall down off the ledge was quite miraculous. “We’re just really, really lucky that we had someone like Juan with us, with his capabilities, because she was looking like she was going to jump in the more distressed she was getting.” Bebe and Lulu have previously been known to run off to chase rabbits in the fields surrounding her smallholding, but when they did notfor several hours, Melanie began to panic. Following frantic social media appeals and a local search that went on late into the night, exhausted Lulu arrived back at her door in the early hours of the next morning. But it wasn’t until the search party ventured close to a local quarry some hours later that they heard Bebe’s tiny bark and knew that she was also still alive. Melanie said: “I was shouting to her, and I actually heard her yelp, so I knew she was alive, which by then was  hours from her being away. “She must have fallen  foot down onto this ledge, just four or five foot above the water. “This water is very deep – . metres deep. She was amazingly lucky to have fallen down there.” Melanie called the emergency services for help and was waiting for a fire safety officer to arrive. But with Bebe becoming ever more distressed, five-time Iron Man veteran Juan decided to embark on the daring rescue mission himself by swimming over to save her. Melanie said: “He just jumped off and launched in, but he’s quite used to open water swimming. “He’s the chair of the triathlon club over here and organises lots of those type of things, and he’s done five ‘Iron Mans’, so he’s fairly tough. “He swam about  metres to Bebe and checkedshe was all right. She was delighted to see him. “She didn’t seem to be hurt, so he picked her up and made the swim back, which was pretty tough as by that time it was pretty cold. “She was trying to help with her little doggy paddle, which was just scratching his face and eyes and chest.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON West CoastSwimmingAnimalsDogsRescue" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i love being kate middleton
story: I love being Kate Middleton lookalike - but got death threat and followed homeAs the Duchess of Cambridge Kate Middleton turns  today, we meet the so-called "repli-Kates" who copy her every move including her mannerisms and outfitsHeidi Agan quit her job in  and made “being Kate” her full-time careerByLucy RobinsonJunior WriterRuby Molyneux:,  Jan | comments Heidi Agan, , from Northamptonshire, is married to painter and decorator Russ, and is mum to son Blake, , and daughter Abi, .I was waitressing when Kate and William got engaged in  and customers always said I looked like her.It was mainly the hair and eyes. They started requesting to be served by “the duchess” and taking pictures.It made me think, “Why not try and do something with this ” So I googled lookalike casting agencies – and was immediately signed up.Four days later I got my first “Kate” job – at Gatwick Airport for the  London Olympics. I was clueless, but I did what the photographer suggested – and loved it.As a single mum at the time, I didn’t believe at first that you could make a living from it.But by  I was able to quit my job and make “being Kate” my full-time career. It wasn’t just the money – crucially it meant spending more time with my children. Being self-employed gives me freedom.  The wages depend on the job – sometimes it’s a -minute job, sometimes it’s all day. So it can be hundreds of pounds – or thousands. There was no training, I just studied her mannerisms and voice, and practised her waving in the mirror. I buy replica clothing from China, around £-£ per Kate outfit, choosing memorable ones, such as the Issa engagement dress that she’s worn several times. I have some LK Bennett clothes, but £ is my top budget per item.I blow-dry my own hair and have mastered the classic, natural make-up Kate prefers. But in real le I’m a jeans and sweatshirt, messy bun kind of person. When Kate had a fringe cut, so did I – and absolutely hated it. I think she did too because it hasn’t made a comeback since. For her pregnancies I wore a fake bump, and ate a bit more cake, it was great. Kate has an enviable figure, so it’s hard work staying in similar shape, especially without her personal trainers and palace swimming pool.  I’m only ft in whereas Kate is ft in, but with heels people don’t notice. After  years I’ve got the hang of it. I work a lot with a Prince William lookalike, Simon Watkinson. We’re friends and people seem disappointed we’re not an actual couple in real le.Every day I keep abreast of Kate’s movements. Just recently I watched a video of her at awith schoolchildren – she was wearing a pink Hobbs coat.If I don’t know where her clothing is from, social media is helpful for tips because a Kate fan will always know the answer.I’ve clocked up hundreds of appearances as Kate and travelled to Australia, Hong Kong and New York.No two days are the same. I’d never have had these experiencesit wasn’t for her. The most bizarre job was at Madame Tussauds, standing in place of the waxwork then jumping out and scaring people! I often get stopped for selfies and mistaken for the duchess and – scarily – I’ve been followed home once. Dealing with internet trolls was the hardest – saying they hate the royals and I don’t look like Kate – but I’ve learnt to just shrug it off. Once, someone posted a death threat, but Facebook quickly dealt with it and the agency I’m signed to vets clients. I’m very careful, I’d never jog around London in full make-up, drawing attention to myself.As Kate turns  I hope she continues championing things such as mental health and child development. She’s become more confident, giving more speeches and wearing bolder colours.I’m a year older than her and my advice to Kate is to just enjoy turning . The Jubilee year will be a good time for her – and me – to shine. Hopefully, there’s longevity in this job and I’ll be Queen one day. If I ever did get to met her I’d probably just wave and say hello. My husband Russ has known me since high school. He’s proud of me but he never comments on whether he fancies the real Kate. After work he’ll just say, “How was your day ” I’ll say, “Great” and that’s that. My kids don’t care what I do – a job is a job after all.Katie Wolfe, , lives in Pennsylvania, USA, and is married to Sean. They have two sons Luke, , and Lincoln, six. At ft in and a UK size -, I’m not the most obvious person to be a Kate lookalike, but ever since I began posting pictures of myself dressed as her on Instagram in  I’ve picked up nearly , followers – and counting.I work with brands who give me clothes, and I’m on my way to earning an income as an influencer. After Kate got engaged I instantly fell in love with her blue Issa engagement dress and her style.  My husband Sean, , often says I look like her and, for me, that’s the greatest compliment because Kate’s the most beautul woman in the world. As social media grew I started following Kate-related Instagram pages and saw there weren’t any fuller-figured lookalikes. I was scared to put myself out there, but Sean encouraged me – “Do it!” he said. “Maybe you’ll inspire somebody .” I stick to natural make-up – a nice base, shaped eyebrows and maybe some eyeliner – and blow-dry my hair with a loose curl.I get friends or Sean to take pictures of me in my garden, mainly. My sons think being an influencer is very cool. As a stay-at-home mum I have a tight budget, so I hunt for eBay bargains, finding things Kate’s worn.It can take hours and it took a whole decade to find a cashmere-blend Ralph Lauren turtleneck sweater dress she wore in , which I managed to get for  . The most expensive item I own is Kate’s Barbour Winter Defence Jacket, a gt from Sean so I don’t know the cost – he’s so supportive. On my bucket list is to get hold of the blue LK Bennett Addison dress Kate wore when the Obamas visited Kensington Palace. It’s absolutely gorgeous! There’s a lovely Instagram community with other “Kates” – we all adore her and share tips. People post, “Where did you get that ” andsomeone can’t afford to buy Kate’s exact version, we all rally around to help find something similar that costs less. I prefer recreating her casual looks, which I can wear a lot. Now other plus-size ladies tell me I’ve inspired them, and that’s sweet because we’re not usually represented.I’ve never thought about losing weight to look like her,anything this has proved I can be me and do this. Thankfully I’ve not had to deal with trolls or any kind of negativity. At  now, Kate inspires me in more ways than just fashion. She’s so graceful and collected, and as an anxiety sufferer I try to channel that. Wearing even just her earrings makes me feel more confident and composed. She’s a great mum, too. I saw a video of Charlotte having a tantrum and thought, “OK, I can cope too” because Kate did it in front of all these important people. It’s been such a positive experience.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Kate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgePrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: kate middleton 40 how duchess
story: Kate Middleton at  - how Duchess has channelled Diana as a royal kids championKate Middleton has been dubbed The Children’s Princess as over the years she has become an advocate for all kids, particularly within the fields of youth mental health and early years developmentThe Duchess of Cambridge meets children during a visit to Reach Academy Feltham in London in  Image: PAByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  Jan | comments It is a gesture that has come naturally to the Duchess of Cambridge : that graceful dip to the pavement or hospital bed, to the level of the smiling child’s face staring up, a natural empathy.Away from grown-ups who scrutinised and critiqued, Kate was at home here from the start, offering reassurance to the young, raising a smile and a giggle. Even having to quickly secure a sickbag from her bodyguard for a pale child spied amid crowds during a  engagement in Coventry didn’t faze her.This all echoes another much-loved Royal from a dferent generation. Kate is following in the footsteps of Princess Diana who made this gesture her own: crouching with a relaxed empathy to listen to young confidences. For Kate, that clear connection with the little ones she meets on her engagements, was to prove the seed and catalyst for what has now become the cornerstone of her royal legacy. As she approaches her th birthday this weekend, with greater standing and responsibility within the royal ranks than ever before, the Duchess – dubbed by fans the Children’s Princess – has now confidently created her niche. Alongside the arrival of her personal role as mum to her and William’s three children, George, eight, Charlotte, six, and Louis, three, Kate has in tandem become an advocate for all children, particularly within the fields of youth mental health and early years development. Perhaps seeing the privilege of her own tots within palace walls, she has decided every UK child needs the same support and opportunities. “Kate connects really beautully with the young. I think that’s very like Diana, but that doesn’t mean that Diana has the exclusivity on that – I think it’s just something that she has within her,” says royal commentator, Ingrid Seward. The advent of motherhood in  with the arrival of Prince George has perhaps cemented natural tendencies and skills. Kate has launched her Royal Foundation Centre for Early Childhood, stating she wants to “raise awareness of why the first five years of le are just so important for our future le outcomes”. And she has been a driving force behind a landmark study on perceptions of early childhood. With patronages of children’s charities including Action for Children, Anna Freud National Centre for Children and Families, East Anglia Children’s Hospices, the Evelina London Children’s Hospital and PlaceBe, she also helped launch the first-ever Children’s Mental Health Week in .  Her personally designed garden at the Cha Flower Show in  was focussed on getting children out into nature to help their wellbeing. And her own brood arrived right on cue to show us how that was done, enthusiastically collecting hazel sticks and swooping gleefully on a rope swing. “I am passionate about improving children’s le chances and giving them opportunities so they can look forward to the best possible futures,” Kate said. She has spoken of her own childhood, enjoying the outdoors with the sporty Middleton family and how time outside with her own young family now make some of her most treasured moments.  And, as Kate follows her passions and carves out a strong role for herself, she is first and foremost ensuring her brood never miss out on her time, as royal children have been prone to in the past. Ingrid explains: “She will actually make sure that she arranges her royal engagements so that she can take the kids to school and be home when they come home, which is pretty dficult to do. “She decided the children were her priority, whatever she was doing. However important her work was to her, the children had to be her priority.” As her three treasured children now continue to grow, so Kate will grow with them, building her own unique position on the royal stage. title: kate middleton jokingly rolled eyes
story: Kate Middleton jokingly rolled eyes when pal mentioned Meghans show Suits, insider claimsMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton, along with their husbands Princes Harry and William, are working through a bitter rt, with both couples said to be upset and angry about recent eventsKate and Meghan reportedly didnt spend much time together ahead of the Duke and Duchesses royal wedding in  Image: PAByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge once jokingly rolled her eyes when a pal mentioned her sister-in-law Meghan Markleaposs hit TV show Suits, an insider has claimed.Kate is said to keep her feelings and opinions on Prince Harry and Meghan private, despite their much-commented on fallout, unlike her husband, Prince William. Commenting on how open the couple are with those closest to them, an insider told The Sunday Times Magazine that William is frank about whataposs on his mind, including family woes.However Kate is % more reserved than him and keeps her feelings private. The insider says that the closest Kate has ever come to revealing her thoughts on the situation was by once jokingly rolling her eyes at the mention of Suits.  Initial reports were that Kate and Meghan had fallen out, however insiders later suggested the strain was actually between William and Harry. In the biography Finding Freedom, authors Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand claimed Meghan and Kate werenapost close as they had nothing in common, rather than because of tension. They say the women didnapost spend much time together before the Sussexes got married in May  and they didnapost get any closer afterwards. They write: Meghan would agree with the assessment that the duchesses were not the best of friends. Their relationship hadnapost progressed much since she was Harryaposs girlfriend. But they were not at war with each other, either. There were awkward moments, such as the day the women happened to cross paths at Kensington Palace , and although both were heading out to go shopping - in the same street - Kate went in her own Range Rover. However in Meghanaposs interview with Oprah Winfrey, she accused Kate of making her cry during the now infamous bridesmaid dress fitting ahead of the Sussexesapos  wedding. Months after the wedding it was reported that the duchesses fell out because Princess Charlotteaposs dress did not fit and further fittings needed to be scheduled. The source added: Kate had only just given birth to her third child, Prince Louis, and was feeling quite ­emotional. It was reported that Kate left the fitting in tears. However, during her interview with Oprah Winfrey, Meghan said the reverse happened and she was actually the one who was upset. She said: A few days before the wedding, she was upset about something pertaining - yes, the issue was correct - about flower girl dresses, and it made me cry, and it really hurt my feelings. Meghan was shocked that what she believes was the reverse of what happened went public, leaving her being blamed for a situation that she wasnapost responsible for and happened to her. Everyone in the institution knew it wasnapost true. I am not sharing that piece about Kate to be in any way disparaging about her. I would hope that she would want that to be corrected, added Meghan. When Oprah tried to get more information, Meghan stated it would not be fair to go into further details as Kate had apologised. She said Kate had apologised and sent flowers, and that all had now been forgiven. title: kate middleton miss out special
story: Kate Middleton to miss out on special birthday honour as she turns  todayThe bells at Westminster Abbey usually ring to mark the birthdays of senior members of the Royal Family but Kate Middleton will miss out on this today, despite her celebrating her thKate Middleton, who turns  today Image: Getty ImagesByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Today is the Duchess of Cambridgeaposs birthday - and this year it is very special one. Our future Queen has hit the milestone age of  - and no doubt she will be celebrating all day with her family and friends. But despite the landmark birthday, Kate is missing out on a special honour usually afforded to members of the Royal Family when they turn another year older.Today, there will be no ringing of the bells at Westminster Abbey, which usually chime on royal birthdays.It had been tradition for senior royals to hear the bells ringing at the Abbey on their birthdays with Kate and Camilla the Duchess of Cornwall included among them. But they were stopped in April  due to Covid and changes were made when they restarted in September .No longer will the bells be rung for the birthdays of Princess Anne, Prince Andrew, Prince Edward, or the Duchess of Cornwall and it is the same for the Cambridges and their children, reports Hello magazine. In future, they will only be heard for the Queen and Prince Charles.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Itaposs unclear exactly how Kate is spending her big day today - although itaposs said that any celebrations will be low-key.However, thereaposs no doubt that husband Prince William and their children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis will be showering her with lovely presents.But it seems William wasnapost always so good at picking the perfect gts for his we, and he once admitted getting her an awful present that Kate has never let him forget.William revealed the bizarre present during an appearance on former England striker Peter Crouch’s podcast on BBC Radio Five Live. In a discussion about gts, Crouch confessed to buying his model we Abbey Clancy a raincoat three years running for her birthday.And William added: I did get my we a pair of binoculars once - sheaposs never let me forget that. That was early on in the courtship that was - think that sealed the deal. It didnapost go well. Honestly, I have no idea why I bought her a pair of binoculars, it seemed like a good idea at the time.
